answers.definition: Fond of someone or something.
answers.sentence: Our family is partial to vacations that take us to the outdoors, like camping and hiking.

answers.definition: In part, incomplete, not whole.
answers.sentence: Our vegetable garden was only a partial success this summer because deer ate some of the plants.

wrongs: A place that sells cooked meats and cheeses.
Not at all fond of someone or something.

answers.definition: A small piece of something, a tiny bit, a speck.
answers.sentence: The particles of sand and soil in a dust storm can be carried thousands of miles.

wrongs: A place that sells cooked meats and cheeses.

answers.definition: Special, set apart from others in a group.
answers.sentence: Michelle liked all the dogs, but that particular puppy was the one he wanted.

wrongs: Eating too much in one sitting, especially sugary foods.

answers.definition: To divide into parts
answers.sentence: North American settlers partitioned the land where buffalo once grazed.

answers.definition: Someting that divides one part of a room, drawer, or area from another.
answers.sentence: The tall bookcase served as a partition, separating the dining room from the living room.

answers.definition: One who takes part in an activity with another person.
answers.sentence: When Peter plays doubles in tennis, he usually chooses Lara to be his partner.

wrongs: Someone who breaks things into pieces.
Showing a lot of concern for others.

answers.definition: A place where recordings, radio broadcases, TV programs, and movies are made.
answers.sentence: The announcer at the television studio showed replays of parts of the game.

answers.definition: A room where an artist, musician, dancer or photographer works or teaches.
answers.sentence: We went to the photographer's studio to get a family portrait.

wrongs: A place where bulls wait for their food.
A tiny place to store winter clothes.
A printed list of questions for getting information.

answers.definition: Attentiveness to learning, concentration on learning.
answers.sentence: My older sister made good grades in every subject because of her studiousness.

wrongs: Someone who always forgets their homework, but just understands things.
A list of questions you have to answer.

answers.definition: An actor who learns the lines of another actor, especially the star, in order to be ready to substitute if needed.
answers.sentence: When the leading lady in the play got sick, her understudy performed well in her place.

wrongs: Someone who lives under a library.
A boy who's gotten really good at vocab words.

answers.definition: To be worthy of.
answers.sentence: Since Amelia had not missed a single chorus practice, she deserved an award for perfect attendance.

wrongs: To give something of high value.

answers.definition: A restaurant worker that serves food.
answers.sentence: We asked our server to bring us another basket of bread as we read the menu.

answers.definition: The player who serves the ball, as in tennis and volleyball.
answers.sentence: Milena is the strongest server of all the girls on the team.

answers.definition: A computer that responds to other computer requests.
answers.sentence: When the server is down, neither our classroom computer not the library computer works.

wrongs: A clean cut into two equal pieces.
Someone who cooks really tasty food.
A person who fixes broken computers.
The basketball player who brings up the ball.

answers.definition: Work done for others, helpful acts.
answers.sentence: The firefighters perform a valuable service for everyone in this city.

wrongs: Resting after a long day of work.

answers.definition: Useful, helpful, able to be used for a long time.
answers.sentence: Victor's hiking boots were still serviceable but too small.

answers.definition: Likely to change or be different.
answers.sentence: The tides are variable during the year because of the position of the sun and the moon.

answers.definition: The amount of change of something from the normal.
answers.sentence: Our class made a chart showing the variation in our town's population over the past twenty years.

answers.definition: A collection of different things, an assortment.
answers.sentence: Dad and I looked at a variety of small flowering plants before selecting one for the kitchen window.

wrongs: A collection that is carefully ordered.
When each thing is exactly the same.
Pleasing to the taste or smell.

answers.definition: Of several different types, not alike.
answers.sentence: The dentist asked his assistant for various tools as he completed the work on my filling.

answers.definition: Comfort, not having to try hard.
answers.sentence: After Brooke practiced the dance step for a week, she could do it with ease.

answers.definition: To reduce the strain.
answers.sentence: When Hector eased up on the rope, he lost the tug-of-war.

answers.definition: Not difficult at all, most simple.
answers.sentence: Because we studied so hard for the last test, it seemed like the easiest one of the year.

wrongs: The one most likely to be punished.

answers.definition: Uncomfortable, not relaxed, worried.
answers.sentence: Lucas was uneasy about giving a speech to the class because he had not practiced at home.

answers.definition: The last part, as of a program or a piece of music.
answers.sentence: After the band members performed several popular tunes, they played the school song as their finale.

wrongs: The best part of the a program or a piece of music.
The oldest part of a program or a piece of music.
A song played when the flag is raised.

answers.definition: A person who is in the last round of a contest.
answers.sentence: We all attended te state spelling bee to cheer for Megan, our school's finalist.

wrongs: A person who has the loudest voice.
A person who is the best at a contest.
A person who is the most tired.
A person who likes taking tests.

answers.definition: At last, at the end.
answers.sentence: After two days of blizzard conditions, the snow finally stopped and a plow made its way down our road.

answers.definition: Having an end, limited.
answers.sentence: Cesar had a finite number of prizes to hand out and was afraid they wouldn't last.

answers.definition: Incomplete, not finished
answers.sentence: When the time ran out, Jeff had to turn in an unfinished test.

answers.definition: Not having any final coating.
answers.sentence: Caroline decided to paint the unfinished wood of the picnic table.
